paragraph.label: 1026-35-a-2
paragraph.content: “Average prime offer rate” means an annual percentage rate that is derived from average interest rates, points, and other loan pricing terms currently offered to <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> by a representative sample of <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> for mortgage transactions that have low-risk pricing characteristics. The <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> publishes average prime offer rates for a broad range of types of transactions in a table updated at least weekly as well as the methodology the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> uses to derive these rates.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-c
paragraph.content: [Reserved]

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Initial payments for a variable-rate transaction consummated on January 1, 2010 are $1,000 per month and the loan agreement permits negative amortization to occur. Under the loan agreement, the first date that a scheduled payment in a different amount may be due is January 1, 2014, but the creditor has the right to change scheduled payments prior to that date if negative amortization occurs. A prepayment penalty is prohibited with this mortgage transaction because the payment may change within the four-year period following consummation.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-Interp-1-ii
interpParagraph.content: Under § 1026.35(b)(2)(iv)(B), a county is underserved during a calendar year if, according to Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) data for the preceding calendar year, no more than two creditors extended covered transactions, as defined in § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, five or more times in the county. Specifically, a county is “underserved” if, in the applicable calendar year's public HMDA aggregate dataset, no more than two creditors have reported five or more first-lien covered transactions with HMDA geocoding that places the properties in that county. For purposes of this determination, because only covered transactions are counted, all first-lien originations (and only first-lien originations) reported in the HMDA data are counted except those for which the owner-occupancy status is reported as “Not owner-occupied” (HMDA code 2), the property type is reported as “Multifamily” (HMDA code 3), the applicant's or co-applicant's race is reported as “Not applicable” (HMDA code 7), or the applicant's or co-applicant's sex is reported as “Not applicable” (HMDA code 4). The most recent HMDA data are available at http://www.ffiec.gov/hmda.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e
paragraph.title: Repayment ability, prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability, prepayment penalties. <ref target="1026-35-a-1" reftype="term">Higher-priced mortgage loans</ref> are subject to the following restrictions:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-1
paragraph.title: Repayment ability.
paragraph.content: Repayment ability. A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> shall not extend <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> based on the value of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s collateral without regard to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s repayment ability as of <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> as provided in § <ref target="1026-34-a-4" reftype="internal">1026.34(a)(4)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2
paragraph.title: Prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Prepayment penalties. A loan may not include a penalty described by § <ref target="1026-32-d-6" reftype="internal">1026.32(d)(6)</ref> unless:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-i
paragraph.content: The penalty is otherwise permitted by law, including § <ref target="1026-32-d-7" reftype="internal">1026.32(d)(7)</ref> if the loan is a mortgage transaction described in § <ref target="1026-32-a" reftype="internal">1026.32(a)</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: Under the terms of the loan:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply after the two-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or an <ref target="1026-32-b-2" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: The amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-3
paragraph.title: Sunset of requirements on repayment ability and prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Sunset of requirements on repayment ability and prepayment penalties. The requirements described in this paragraph <ref target="1026-35-e" reftype="internal">(e)</ref> shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on January 9, 2014.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Payment change. Section 1026.35(e)(2) provides that a loan subject to this section may not have a penalty described by § 1026.32(d)(6) unless certain conditions are met. Section 1026.35(e)(2)(ii)(C) lists as a condition that the amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following consummation. For examples showing whether a prepayment penalty is permitted or prohibited in connection with particular payment changes, see comment 32(d)(7)(iv)-1. Those examples, however, include a condition that § 1026.35(e)(2) does not include: The condition that, at consummation, the consumer's total monthly debt payments may not exceed 50 percent of the consumer's monthly gross income. For guidance about circumstances in which payment changes are not considered payment changes for purposes of this section, see comment 32(d)(7)(iv)-2.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Negative amortization. Section 1026.32(d)(2) provides that a loan described in § 1026.32(a) may not have a payment schedule with regular periodic payments that cause the principal balance to increase. Therefore, the commentary to § 1026.32(d)(7)(iv) does not include examples of payment changes in connection with negative amortization. The following examples show whether, under § 1026.35(e)(2), prepayment penalties are permitted or prohibited in connection with particular payment changes, when a loan agreement permits negative amortization:

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: Initial payments for a variable-rate transaction consummated on January 1, 2010, are $1,000 per month and the loan agreement permits negative amortization to occur. Under the loan agreement, the first date that a scheduled payment in a different amount may be due is January 1, 2014, and the creditor does not have the right to change scheduled payments prior to that date even if negative amortization occurs. A prepayment penalty is permitted with this mortgage transaction provided that the other § 1026.35(e)(2) conditions are met, that is: Provided that the prepayment penalty is permitted by other applicable law, the penalty expires on or before December 31, 2011, and the penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the creditor or its affiliate.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: Initial payments for a variable-rate transaction consummated on January 1, 2010 are $1,000 per month and the loan agreement permits negative amortization to occur. Under the loan agreement, the first date that a scheduled payment in a different amount may be due is January 1, 2014, but the creditor has the right to change scheduled payments prior to that date if negative amortization occurs. A prepayment penalty is prohibited with this mortgage transaction because the payment may change within the four-year period following consummation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a
paragraph.title: Refinancings.
paragraph.content: Refinancings. A refinancing occurs when an existing obligation that was subject to this subpart is satisfied and replaced by a new obligation undertaken by the same <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. A refinancing is a new transaction requiring new disclosures to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. The new finance charge shall include any unearned portion of the old finance charge that is not credited to the existing obligation. The following shall not be treated as a refinancing:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-1
paragraph.content: A renewal of a single payment obligation with no change in the original terms.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-2
paragraph.content: A reduction in the annual percentage rate with a corresponding change in the payment schedule.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-3
paragraph.content: An agreement involving a court proceeding.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-4
paragraph.content: A change in the payment schedule or a change in collateral requirements as a result of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s default or delinquency, unless the rate is increased, or the new amount financed exceeds the unpaid balance plus earned finance charge and premiums for continuation of insurance of the types described in § <ref target="1026-4-d" reftype="internal">1026.4(d)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-a-5
paragraph.content: The renewal of optional insurance purchased by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> and added to an existing transaction, if disclosures relating to the initial purchase were provided as required by this subpart.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b
paragraph.title: Assumptions.
paragraph.content: Assumptions. An assumption occurs when a <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> expressly agrees in writing with a subsequent <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> to accept that <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> as a primary obligor on an existing <ref target="1026-2-a-24" reftype="term">residential mortgage transaction</ref>. Before the assumption occurs, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> shall make new disclosures to the subsequent <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, based on the remaining obligation. If the finance charge originally imposed on the existing obligation was an add-on or discount finance charge, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> need only disclose:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-1
paragraph.content: The unpaid balance of the obligation assumed.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-2
paragraph.content: The total charges imposed by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> in connection with the assumption.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-3
paragraph.content: The information required to be disclosed under § <ref target="1026-18-k" reftype="internal">1026.18(k)</ref>, <ref target="1026-18-l" reftype="internal">(l)</ref>, <ref target="1026-18-m" reftype="internal">(m)</ref>, and <ref target="1026-18-n" reftype="internal">(n)</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-4
paragraph.content: The annual percentage rate originally imposed on the obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-b-5
paragraph.content: The payment schedule under § <ref target="1026-18-g" reftype="internal">1026.18(g)</ref> and the total of payments under § <ref target="1026-18-h" reftype="internal">1026.18(h)</ref> based on the remaining obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c
paragraph.title: Variable-rate adjustments.
paragraph.content: Variable-rate adjustments. Except as provided in paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref> of this section, an adjustment to the interest rate with or without a corresponding adjustment to the payment in a variable-rate transaction subject to § <ref target="1026-19-b" reftype="internal">1026.19(b)</ref> is an event requiring new disclosures to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. At least once each year during which an interest rate adjustment is implemented without an accompanying payment change, and at least 25, but no more than 120, calendar days before a payment at a new level is due, the following disclosures, as applicable, must be delivered or placed in the mail:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-1
paragraph.content: The current and prior interest rates.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2
paragraph.content: The index values upon which the current and prior interest rates are based.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-3
paragraph.content: The extent to which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> has foregone any increase in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-4
paragraph.content: The contractual effects of the adjustment, including the payment due after the adjustment is made, and a statement of the loan balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-5
paragraph.content: The payment, if different from that referred to in paragraph <ref target="1026-20-c-4" reftype="internal">(c)(4)</ref> of this section, that would be required to fully amortize the loan at the new interest rate over the remainder of the loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d
paragraph.content: Information provided in accordance with variable-rate subsequent disclosure regulations of other Federal agencies may be substituted for the disclosure required by paragraph <ref target="1026-20-c" reftype="internal">(c)</ref> of this section.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D
paragraph.content: Neither the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> nor its <ref target="1026-32-b-2" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> maintains an escrow account of the type described in paragraph <ref target="1026-35-b-1" reftype="internal">(b)(1)</ref> of this section for any extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> secured by real property or a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or its <ref target="1026-32-b-2" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> currently services, other than:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-1
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established for first-lien <ref target="1026-35-a-1" reftype="term">higher-priced mortgage loans</ref> on or after April 1, 2010, and before June 1, 2013; or

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-D-2
paragraph.content: Escrow accounts established after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> as an accommodation to distressed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> to assist such <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> in avoiding default or foreclosure.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii
paragraph.content: Under the terms of the loan:

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply after the two-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The penalty will not apply if the source of the prepayment funds is a refinancing by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> or an <ref target="1026-32-b-2" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: The amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: A county is considered “rural” for a given calendar year based on the most recent available UIC designations, which are updated by the USDA-ERS once every ten years. As an example, assume a creditor makes first-lien covered transactions in County X during calendar year 2014, and the most recent UIC designations have been published in the second quarter of 2013. To determine “rural” status for County X during calendar year 2014, the creditor will use the 2013 UIC designations. However, to determine “rural” status for County X during 2012 or 2013, the creditor would use the UIC designations last published in 2003.

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iii-A
paragraph.content: During the preceding calendar year, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> extended more than 50 percent of its total covered transactions, as defined by § 1026.43(b)(1), secured by a first lien, on properties that are located in counties that are either “rural” or “underserved,” as set forth in paragraph (b)(2)(iv) of th<ref target="1026-35-b-2-iv" reftype="internal">is section</ref>;

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-Interp-2
interpParagraph.content: Examples.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-Interp-2-i
interpParagraph.content: A county is considered “rural” for a given calendar year based on the most recent available UIC designations, which are updated by the USDA-ERS once every ten years. As an example, assume a creditor makes first-lien covered transactions in County X during calendar year 2014, and the most recent UIC designations have been published in the second quarter of 2013. To determine “rural” status for County X during calendar year 2014, the creditor will use the 2013 UIC designations. However, to determine “rural” status for County X during 2012 or 2013, the creditor would use the UIC designations last published in 2003.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-Interp-2-ii
interpParagraph.content: A county is considered “underserved” for a given calendar year based on the most recent available HMDA data. For example, assume a creditor makes first-lien covered transactions in County Y during calendar year 2013, and the most recent HMDA data is for calendar year 2012, published in the third quarter of 2013. To determine “underserved” status for County Y in calendar year 2013 for the purposes of qualifying for the “rural or underserved” exemption in calendar year 2014, the creditor will use the 2012 HMDA data.

interpParagraph.label: 1026-35-e-2-ii-C-Interp-1
interpParagraph.content: Payment change. Section 1026.35(e)(2) provides that a loan subject to this section may not have a penalty described by § 1026.32(d)(6) unless certain conditions are met. Section 1026.35(e)(2)(ii)(C) lists as a condition that the amount of the periodic payment of principal or interest or both may not change during the four-year period following consummation.
